monster.name: Claw

trait.name: Light Sensitivity
entries: While in bright light, Claw has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Shadow Teleport {@recharge 5}
entries: As a bonus action, Claw can teleport to an unoccupied space within 30 feet of him, provided that both the space he's teleporting from and his destination are in dim light or darkness. The destination need not be within line of sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Claw makes one claw and one scimitar attack.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d4 + 3}) slashing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

legendaryHeader: Claw can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Claw regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: Claw makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Recharge Shadow
entries: Claw regains his Shadow Teleport trait.

legendary.name: Torture Mind (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Claw targets a creature that he can see within 30 feet of him. The creature must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage and be {@condition frightened} until the start of the creature's next turn.

Claw is a half-meenlock, half-human interrogator who works for the Zhentarim. He has a mysterious past, though what is known is that he was at one point a high-ranking member of the Xanathar, before they tried some fucky shit. Through magical protection, he was able to retain some of his humanity from the meenlock conversion ritual.

spellcasting.name: Shared Spellcasting (Coven Only)
headerEntries: When at least four sprouts are within 30 feet of eachother, they can each cast the following spells from the druid's spell list but must share the spell slots among themselves:
At will: {@spell druidcraft}, {@spell pass without trace}, {@spell speak with plants}
footerEntries: The sprouts' spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}, +4 to hit with spell attacks).

trait.name: Sprout Coven
entries: A group of at least 4 sprouts may form a coven, working together to serve the one who planted them. In such a coven, the sprouts act on the same initiative count.

trait.name: Goodberry Vitality
entries: Each sproutchild has a small {@spell goodberry} growing from their heads. A creature can use its action to consume one of the berries, provided the sprout is willing. If the sprout sees the one who grew them fall {@condition unconscious}, the sprout will use its action to feed them a berry, restoring 1 hit point. If the sprout uses its goodberry or somehow loses its goodberry, the sprout will wither away and die after 1 minute.

trait.name: Withering With You
entries: A sprout will only last 1 hour; however, a {@spell plant growth} spell cast with the long-term use or a similar magical effect will make the sprouts last indefinitely. The spell will keep the sprouts alive throughout the process, and once the process is finished, each sprout gains {@dice 1d4} maximum hit points. A {@spell dispel magic} or similar effect instantly withers and kills all of the sprouts (even if only one is targeted).

action.name: Fire Thorns
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 1} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4 - 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Thorn Slap
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4 - 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Last Resort (Coven Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. All of the sprouts in a single coven combine their remaining druidic magic to grow into a single Treant. After growing into a treant, the sprouts must immediately make a Last Resort attack before withering away.

legendary.name: Last Resort (Coven Only)
entries: The sprouts take the Last Resort action.

trait.name: Vengeful Rage
entries: If Delhoor sees Sen'Gar slain, Delhoor goes into a blind rage, targeting only the foe that dealt the final blow to Sen'Gar. During this rage, Delhoor gains resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, has advantage on strength saving throws and ability checks.

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, Delhoor can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, Delhoor can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If Delhoor fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Delhoor can make 2 Halberd attacks per turn. If Sen'Gar has died in this combat he can make 3.

action.name: Halberd
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

reaction.name: Geminate Shield
entries: If Delhoor sees or hears an attack that hits Sen'Gar, Delhoor can swap places with Sen'Gar, provided they are within 5 feet of eachother, taking the damage that Sen'Gar would have taken instead.

Sen'Gar and Delhoor are orc twins born deep in undermountain, and residents of Skullport. Their rough upbringing turned them to a life of crime, and eventually they became skilled assassins, who venture across Faerun to complete their contracts. Long ago, a clone of Manshoon helped them escape undermountain, and as such they owe him a great favor. While not members of Zhentarim, they consider themselves servants of Bane, and as such have alligned goals.
Delhoor, the Decapitator

Delhoor, the brother of Sen'Gar has a less magical upbringing than his brother; however, he loves him dearly and would do everything in his power to protect him. Rather than turn towards the magical, Delhoor has always been strong, and as such embraces his brutish nature to protect Sen. While Delhoor believes his life has been completely mundane, his blood is magically cursed, which gives him supernatural strength.
Delhoor wears the top half of a golden skull, along with a wicked black and crude halberd, which stands at about 9 feet tall. He wears spiked plate armor.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The villainous shadow can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the villainous shadow can take the Hide action as a bonus action. Its stealth bonus is also improved to +6.

trait.name: Sunlight Weakness
entries: While in sunlight, the villainous shadow has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

action.name: Strength Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) necrotic damage, and the target's Strength score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}. The target dies if this reduces its Strength to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.
If a non-evil humanoid dies from this attack, a new shadow rises from the corpse {@dice 1d4} hours later.

reaction.name: Remain in Dark
entries: If an active source of light within 60 feet of the villainous shadow moves towards it, it can move up to 15 feet. This movement does not provoke attacks of opportunity.

legendary.name: Hide
entries: The villainous shadow takes the Hide action.

legendary.name: Consume Light (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The villainous shadow snuffs out any non-magical sources of light (torches, flames, lanterns) within 60 feet of it.

legendary.name: Inhabit Shadow
entries: The villainous shadow teleports to a creature it can see within 30 feet, provided that the shadow and the target creature are not in bright light. The target must make a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of the targets next turn.

fluff.name: Shadow
entries: Shadows are undead that resemble dark exaggerations of humanoid shadows.

entries.name: Dark Disposition
entries: From the darkness, the shadow reaches out to feed on living creatures' vitality. They can consume any living creature, but they are especially drawn to creatures untainted by evil. A creature that lives a life of goodness and piety consigns its basest impulses and strongest temptations to the darkness where the shadows hunger. As a shadow drains its victim's strength and physical form, the victim's shadow darkens and begins to move of its own volition. In death, the creature's shadow breaks free, becoming a new undead shadow hungry for more life to consume.

If a creature from which a shadow has been created somehow returns to life, its undead shadow senses the return. The shadow might seek its "parent" to vex or slay. Whether the shadow pursues its living counterpart, the creature that birthed the shadow no longer casts one until the monster is destroyed.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A shadow doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Sen'Gar is a 9th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). Sen'Gar has the following warlock spells known:

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, Sen'Gar can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Sen'Gar can make two spell attacks (of the three listed below), or one Vampiric Touch spell attack and one of the three eldritch spells.

action.name: Eldritch Push
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 3}) force damage, and the target has to make a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be pushed 10 feet away.

action.name: Eldritch Fang
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) force damage, and the target has to make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. This saving throw can be repeated at the end of a {@condition poisoned} creature's turn.

action.name: Eldritch Whip
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 15 ft., three targets. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) force damage.

action.name: Vulture Cane
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage and the target must succeed a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw against disease or be infected with {@disease feathered death|Zuishin|}.

action.name: Maddening Gas {@recharge 4}
entries: Sen'Gar uses one of the canisters of magical gas that he has at his disposal. All creatures within a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on Sen'Gar must succeed a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw against poison or be afflicted with short-term madness (roll on the Short-Term Madness table in the DMG). This saving throw can be repeated at the end of a creature's turn, ending itself on a success.

reaction.name: Bloody Vengeance
entries: Upon seeing Delhoor killed, Sen'Gar can use his magic to raise a {@creature Water Elemental|MM|Blood Elemental} from his corpse. The Blood Elemental has the same statistics as a Water Elemental, except it does not speak Aquan and follows Sen'Gar's orders.

legendary.name: Maddening Gas
entries: Sen'Gar takes the Maddening Gas action.

legendary.name: Vulture Talon
entries: Sen'Gar uses his Vulture Cane attack.

legendary.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Sen'Gar takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; Sen'Gar can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:
1. Sen'Gar commands the nearby vultures to swarm the battlefield, making it difficult terrain for everyone except Sen'Gar and Delhoor, and lightly obscuring the area.

2. Sen'Gar commands the vultures to harrass a single creature, the creature must succeed a {@dc} 14 Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for the whole round. While {@condition blinded}, the creature has half-cover from the vultures.

3. Sen'Gar commands the vultures to fly around in a 30-foot-radius ring centered on an area he can see. Creatures (aside from Sen'Gar and Delhoor) can only leave this ring with a {@dc 10} Athletics check, taking their action. This ring provides total cover from the inside and out.

Sen'Gar and Delhoor are orc twins born deep in undermountain, and residents of Skullport. Their rough upbringing turned them to a life of crime, and eventually they became skilled assassins, who venture across Faerun to complete their contracts. Long ago, a clone of Manshoon helped them escape undermountain, and as such they owe him a great favor. While not members of Zhentarim, they consider themselves servants of Bane, and as such have alligned goals.
Sen'Gar, the Skulking Singer

Sen'Gar one day found a gross cyst growing from his neck, which eventually grew to the size of a fist. This is when it began to speak to him. The cyst offered great power in exchange for the spreading of their disease, to which Sen'Gar obliged. He uses vultures to spread quite horrifying magic diseases, the likes of which have never before been encountered in Faerun. Sen'Gar dons the skull of a giant vulture, and uses magical gases to manipulate wild animals. However, there is a particular flock of vultures that follows Sen'Gar, eating the trail of bodies he leaves in his wake.

trait.name: Water Form
entries: The elemental can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Freeze
entries: If the elemental takes cold damage, it partially freezes; its speed is reduced by 20 ft. until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Whelm {@recharge 4}
entries: Each creature in the elemental's space must make a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw. On a failure, a target takes 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If it is Large or smaller, it is also {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and unable to breathe unless it can breathe water. If the saving throw is successful, the target is pushed out of the elemental's space.

The elemental can grapple one Large creature or up to two Medium or smaller creatures at one time. At the start of each of the elemental's turns, each target {@condition grappled} by it takes 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. A creature within 5 feet of the elemental can pull a creature or object out of it by taking an action to make a {@dc 14} Strength check and succeeding.

A water elemental is a cresting wave that rolls across the ground, becoming nearly invisible at it courses through a larger body of water. It engulfs creatures that stand against it, filling their mouths and lungs as easily as it smothers flame.

Elementals are incarnations of the elements that make up the universe: air, earth, fire, and water. Though little more than animated energy on their own planes of existence, they can be called on by spellcasters and powerful beings to take shape and perform tasks.

entries.name: Living Elements
entries: On its home plane, an elemental is a bodiless life force. Its dim consciousness manifests as a physical shape only when focused by the power of magic. A wild spirit of elemental force has no desire except to course through the element of its native plane. Like beasts of the Material Plane, these elemental spirits have no society or culture, and little sense of being.

entries.name: Conjured by Magic
entries: Certain spells and magic items can conjure an elemental, summoning it from the Inner Planes to the Material Plane. Elementals instinctively resent being pulled from their native planes and bound into service. A creature that summons an elemental must assert force of will to control it.

entries.name: Bound and Shaped
entries: Powerful magic can bind an elemental spirit into a material template that defines a specific use and function. Invisible stalkers are air elementals bound to a specific form, in the same way that water elementals can be shaped into water weirds.

entries.name: Elemental Nature
entries: An elemental doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Greater Shapechanger
entries: The villainous doppelganger can use its action to polymorph into a Small or Medium humanoid it has seen, either physically or through reading a creature's thoughts, or back into its true form. Its statistics, other than its size, are the same in each form; however, the villainous doppelganger can use one of the features of a creature it transforms into. For example, transforming into a great lightning-using spellcaster may grant the villainous doppelganger a single lightning bolt spell. Or transforming into a barbarian may give them the option to use their Rage feature. In general, the features granted by this should not push the villainous doppelganger's CR by more than 1 (see DMG Monster Statistics by CR table). Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: In the first round of a combat, the villainous doppelganger has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it surprised.

trait.name: Surprise Attack
entries: If the villainous doppelganger surprises a creature and hits it with an attack during the first round of combat, the target takes an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The villainous doppelganger makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Greater Read Thoughts
entries: The villainous doppelganger magically reads the surface thoughts of one creature within 60 feet of it. The effect can penetrate barriers, but 3 ft. of wood or dirt, 2 ft. of stone, 2 inches of metal, or a thin sheet of lead blocks it. While the target is in range, the doppelganger can continue reading its thoughts, as long as the doppelganger's concentration isn't broken (as if concentrating on a spell). While reading the target's mind, the doppelganger has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) and Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, and {@skill Persuasion}) checks against the target. The Villainous Doppelganger can share this connection through its telepathy, granting the benefits of it to each creature of its choice that its telepathy can reach.

legendary.name: Greater Shapechanger
entries: The villainous doppelganger takes the action described by its Greater Shapechanger trait.

legendary.name: Read Thoughts
entries: The villainous doppelganger uses the Greater Read Thoughts action.

Doppelgangers are devious shapeshifters that take on the appearance of other humanoids, throwing off pursuit or luring victims to their doom with misdirection and disguise. Few creatures spread fear, suspicion, and deceit better than doppelgangers. Found in every land and culture, they can take on the guise of any individual of any race.

entries.name: Stealing Secrets
entries: A doppelganger's adopted form allows it to blend into almost any group or community, but its transformation doesn't impart languages, mannerisms, memory, or personality. Doppelgangers often follow or capture creatures they intend to impersonate, studying them and probing their minds for secrets. A doppelganger can read a creature's surface thoughts, allowing it to glean that creature's name, desires, and fears, along with a few scattered memories. A doppelganger impersonating a specific creature as part of a long-term plot might keep its double alive and close at hand for weeks, probing the victim's mind daily to learn how to behave and speak authentically.

entries.name: Hedonistic Swindlers
entries: Doppelgangers work alone or in small groups, with group roles shifting from con to con. While one doppelganger takes the place of a murdered merchant or noble, the others take on a number of identities as circumstances warrant, playing the parts of family or servants while they live off the victim's riches.

entries.name: Changelings
entries: Doppelgangers are too lazy or self-interested to raise their young. They assume attractive male forms and seduce women, leaving them to raise their progeny. A doppelganger child appears to be a normal member of its mother's species until it reaches adolescence, at which point it discovers its true nature and is driven to seek out its kind to join them.
